item.title: Tony Abbott, Australian Premier, Vows to Fight Leadership Challenge
item.description: The embattled prime minister urged members of his Liberal Party on Friday to choose “stability” after a junior lawmaker called for a vote next week.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Acts Committed in Islam’s Name Betray Faith, Obama Says
item.description: The talk of terrorism in a speech by President Obama at the National Prayer Breakfast was the sharpest note in an address that was otherwise a reflection on religion and humility.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Genital Cutting Cases Seen More as Immigration Rises
item.description: As the number of African immigrants in the United States has grown, so too has the number of women living in this country who have undergone genital cutting.
item.category: American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
item.dc:creator: By JULIE TURKEWITZ
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariama Bojang, 25, a native of Gambia, said shame kept her from seeing a doctor after her genitals were cut as a girl.

item.title: U.S. and Europe Working to End Ukraine Fighting
item.description: As the White House weighs sending arms to bolster Ukraine’s forces, Secretary of State John Kerry is joining the leaders of Germany and France in Kiev to bolster peace efforts.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A city official in Donetsk, Ukraine, inspected a building that local residents said was damaged by shelling on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Malawi: Estimate of Floods’ Toll Rises
item.description: More than 300,000 people have been displaced by flooding in Malawi, almost twice as many as previously estimated, the United Nations Children’s Fund said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Small Rise in New Cases Shows Ebola Hanging On
item.description: A weekly increase in new cases, the first this year, was worrisome because some of them were patients who had not been listed for monitoring, health officials said.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: New Middle East Envoy Is Appointed
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Thursday that he had appointed Nickolay E. Mladenov, a Bulgarian diplomat and statesman who has been his special representative in Iraq, as his new special Middle East peace envoy.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: India: Christians Protest Attacks
item.description: The police in New Delhi detained hundreds of Christian protesters on Thursday as they prepared to march to the home minister’s residence to demand that the government investigate recent attacks against churches.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Jordan: Jihadist Cleric Freed From Jail
item.description: Jordan released Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a leading jihadist cleric, from prison on Thursday, according to the official Petra news agency.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Security Strategy Recognizes U.S. Limits
item.description: In his second, and final, national security strategy on Friday, President Obama will be making a stronger case than he did five years ago for robust American leadership.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Jordanians Step Up Bombing Raids on ISIS
item.description: Black Hawk helicopters have been sent to Erbil to speed the rescue of downed pilots in Islamic State territory.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Memo From Rosny-Sous-Bois: Old Tradition of Secularism Clashes With France’s New Reality
item.description: In the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo killings, there are new questions about the concept of state secularism and whether it is being fairly applied in a France where an estimated five million Muslims live and worship.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mosque in the Bosquets district of Clichy-sous-Bois. Islam does not easily accept restrictions on the public exercise of religion.

item.title: Promise of Europe Lures Syrians and Smugglers
item.description: An operative in a Turkish-based smuggling operation who organizes cargo ships for migrants says he and his associates are driven by a desire to help.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: The harbor of Side, a small resort town on the Mediterranean Sea in western Turkey and a departure point for Syrian migrants heading for Europe.

item.title: Jordan, Unabashed, Announces Latest Bombing Raid on ISIS Targets
item.description: After the brutal killing of a pilot, Jordan appeared to be redoubling its participation in the anti-Islamic State coalition.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RANYA KADRI and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: King Abdullah II of Jordan, left, offered his condolences on Thursday to Safi al-Kasasbeh, the father of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, in Karak, Jordan.

item.title: At War Blog: Which Movies and Television Shows Get Veterans Right? Or Wrong?
item.description: A retired Army pilot has started a program to grade television shows and movies on how fairly and accurately they portray military veterans. If you’re a veteran, tell us what onscreen portrayals of post 9-11 veterans got it right, or made you cringe.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVE PHILLIPPS
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chris Marvin at a panel discussion last month at the National Geographic Society in Washington. Mr. Marvin's organization, Got Your 6, fights stereotypes of military veterans in movies and on television.

item.title: Boko Haram, and Massacres Ruled by Whim
item.description: Forced marriage, slavery and imprisonment are vital institutions for the militants, the refugees say. And casually meted-out death is common.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Nigerian soldiers in Maiduguri. Boko Haram militants have been attacking the city and terrorizing civilians in the towns around it.

item.title: Greek Debt Diplomacy Doesn’t Sell Well in Germany
item.description: In Berlin, as in Frankfurt, Greece’s new finance minister receives few signs that creditors are open to renegotiating his country’s bailout loans.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Wolfgang Schäuble, left, the German finance minister, and Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, hold a joint news conference after a private meeting Thursday in Berlin.

item.title: Gauguin Painting Is Said to Fetch $300 Million
item.description: The sale of an 1892 Gauguin oil painting, “Nafea Faa Ipoipo (When Will You Marry?),” was confirmed by the seller, Rudolf Staechelin.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT REYBURN and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: Gauguin’s “Nafea Faa Ipoipo (When Will You Marry?),” from 1892, was sold by a collector in Switzerland in a private transaction.

item.title: Ex-Spymaster Is Called to Testify in Investigation of Argentine Prosecutor’s Death
item.description: The former intelligence official was said to have helped Alberto Nisman, found dead last month, in his inquiry into a 1994 bombing in Buenos Aires.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Venezuela Files Charges Accusing Pharmacy Executives of Economic Sabotage
item.description: The authorities claim that a pharmacy chain is trying to destabilize the economy by allowing a long line to form outside one of its stores.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
